overview_of_class: This seminar on American foreign policy will explore the American role in the world from 1961 to the present. Attention will be focused on the Bush National Security Doctrine, the American interventions in Iraq, Afghanistan and Libya; the impact of September 11, 2001; of terrorism on the Bush and Obama foreign policies; the Obama response to the Arab Spring of 2011, and the response to the ISIS threat in Syria and Iraq. Sessions will address the Cold War context of American foreign policy in the early 1960s and the US-Soviet confrontation over Berlin and Cuba; the American involvement in Vietnam and its impact; the period of détente followed by the resurgence of American power in the 1980s; the waning and ending of the Cold War, the emergence and spread of globalization during the last two decades; the impact of the financial crisis of 2008-9 and of the rising influence of China, India and Iran on the future of American hegemony; and, the Obama "pivot" toward Asia. The course will address not only geopolitical issues, but also decision-making and the interaction between public opinion and foreign policy. Some background in American foreign policy, international relations or political science is desirable for students signing up for this seminar.
